head.title: An Accounting of Daily Gun Deaths

hedline.hl1: An Accounting of Daily Gun Deaths

block.p: As a single event, the shootings last week at Virginia Tech were horrific in scale. But every day in the United States, dozens of people die from gunfire.

In 2004, the most recent year for which figures are available, an average of about 81 people died everyday from gunfire in the United States. The chart below gives a rough accounting of who was killed, and how.
As a single event, the shootings last week at Virginia Tech were horrific in scale. But every day in the United States, dozens of people die from gunfire.

In 2004, the most recent year for which figures are available, an average of about 81 people died everyday from gunfire in the United States. The chart below gives a rough accounting of who was killed, and how.
All told, 29,569 people were killed that year by firearms, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Another 64,389 were injured, about 176 per day.
On the chart, each bullet represents one of the those 81 deaths. They are grouped by the age of the victims, and color-coded to indicate the cause of each fatality:
The daily figures are approximations, rounded to the nearest whole number from this calculation: Total 2004 deaths in each group, divided by the 366 days that year.

Because some minority groups have relatively fewer gun deaths, they don't appear in a daily tally. But 281 American Indians were killed by guns in 2004, the same proportion of that population as whites; 398 Asians were killed, a rate one-third of whites.
To view more statistics on deaths and injuries by gunfire and other causes, visit cdc.gov/ncipc/wisqars/.

Correction: April 29, 2007, Sunday A chart last Sunday on daily gun deaths in the United States included an extraneous symbol in some editions. The symbol, a bullet, represented a single death of a person over 40. There should have been 39 bullets depicted, as the text indicated, not 40.
